author: Andy Anderson
bottom_line: Today, people could still trigger avalanches where slabs of wind-blown snow exist on open slopes near ridges and gullies and on steep slopes in sheltered areas where storm snow has not bonded to the old snow. Strong sun this afternoon could make it easier to trigger an avalanche and may cause some wet snow to slide downhill. Move to terrain not steep enough for snow to slide downhill if you see signs of unstable snow, like recent avalanches or cracking in the snow surface, or if you have any doubt about the slope's stability.
hazard_discussion:
• Yesterday observers reported a small wind slab avalanche on Elephant's Hump and cracking in wind-loaded areas on Elephant's Hump and Incline Lake Peak by midday.
  • Ski cuts on steep test slopes on Jakes and Incline Lake Peak caused sluffs of loose storm snow that slide on top of the old snow surfaces (crusts or the thin layer of old snow above the crusts). 
  • A wet loose avalanche also released in response to a skier on a steep slope around 7000 ft in the Mt. Judah area yesterday.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Triggering a wind slab remains possible today, where strong SW winds have loaded snow onto leeward-facing slopes near ridges, open wind-exposed slopes, and gullies. The winds will remain strong enough to blow snow today and may keep piling wind-blown snow onto these wind slabs in some places. The most fragile wind slabs exist on near and above treeline NW-N-NE-E-SE aspects. Wind slab avalanches could involve enough snow to bury or injure a person. New cornices will exist along ridges and above wind-loaded slopes. As the sun comes out this afternoon, it could make wind slabs easier to trigger on sunny slopes. 

Recent avalanches, blowing snow, cracking in wind-blown snow, and new cornices indicate the presence of unstable wind slabs. If you see signs of unstable wind slabs, bypass those areas for more sheltered slopes without signs of wind-loading.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wind Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wind Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) formed by the wind. Wind typically transports snow from the upwind sides of terrain features and deposits snow on the downwind side. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow, and can range from soft to hard. Wind slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Storm slab avalanches also remain possible today due to poor bonding between the old snow surfaces and the new storm snow. In some places, the fresh snow may not have enough cohesion to fail as a slab, and it may slide off the old crusts as loose snow. In other places, the new snow may fail as a storm slab. Unstable storm slabs could linger on any steep slope including below treeline slopes and other typically sheltered areas. This afternoon, strong sun on new snow could make it easier to trigger storm slabs on sunny slopes.

Look for cracking in the storm snow and feel for different layers of snow as you travel through the terrain. If you see any signs of storm snow weakness or doubt a slope's stability, move to lower-angle, non-avalanche terrain.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Storm Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Storm Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer (a slab) of new snow that breaks within new snow or on the old snow surface. Storm-slabs typically last between a few hours and few days (following snowfall). Storm-slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: When the strong March sunshine comes out this afternoon, it could provide enough warming for some wet loose avalanche activity on steep slopes. Some of these could entrain enough snow to cause problems, and terrain traps like gullies, cliffs, or creeks would amplify the potential consequences. Areas that stay cloudy and cool will have less potential for wet snow problems.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wet Loose
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wet Loose avalanches are the release of wet unconsolidated snow or slush. These avalanches typically occur within layers of wet snow near the surface of the snowpack, but they may quickly gouge into lower snowpack layers. Like Loose Dry Avalanches, they start at a point and entrain snow as they move downhill, forming a fan-shaped avalanche. Other names for loose-wet avalanches include point-release avalanches or sluffs. Loose Wet avalanches can trigger slab avalanches that break into deeper snow layers.
